title-group.article-title: Towards a professional supervision culture: The development of social work supervision in Aotearoa New Zealand

contrib-group.aff: The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong

author-notes.corresp: Kieran O’Donoghue, School of Health and Social Services, Massey University, Palmerston North, New Zealand. Email: K.B.ODonoghue@massey.ac.nz

fn.p: Kieran O’Donoghue, PhD, to whom correspondence should be addressed, is the Director of Social Work and Social Policy at Massey University, New Zealand.
Ming-sum Tsui is Professor of Social Work, Department of Applied Social Sciences, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong.

abstract.p: This article reviews the development of social work supervision within New Zealand (NZ) and identifies that supervision in NZ has developed a distinctive professional culture in four respects: recognition and acceptance of plurality and diversity, culturally based approaches, use of the concept of cultural supervision, and commitment to competent social work practice. From the literature reviewed it is asserted that New Zealand’s experience provides valuable insights and learning for supervision internationally.

body.p: Not surprisingly, the literature on social work supervision in New Zealand is generally not well-known outside the country. The aims of this article are two-fold: first, to expose social work supervision in New Zealand to the wider international community; and, second, to argue that New Zealand’s experience provides valuable insights and learning for supervision internationally. This argument is presented in the form of a comprehensive literature review of the New Zealand social work supervision literature, drawn from the New Zealand social work journals, published conference proceedings, social work and supervision books, monographs, theses and research reports. This literature was analyzed qualitatively with the two key sensitizing concepts (see Patton, 2002), Nash’s stages of New Zealand social work history (2001) and O’Donoghue’s New Zealand supervision narrative (2003). These concepts provided the analytical frame for locating social work supervision within the context of the development of New Zealand as a nation, its social services and its social work profession. Consequently, the development of New Zealand society, its social services and social work prior to the emergence of literature in the late 1960s will be overviewed first in order to provide a contextual background for the discussion of the themes present within the New Zealand supervision literature.

sec.title: New Zealand society, its social services and social work
sec.p: Twenty-first century New Zealand society is socially diverse with differences pertaining to age, gender, class, sexual orientation and religious affiliation and, to a certain extent, is similar to other English-speaking Western countries (McLennan et al., 2000; Statistics New Zealand, 2007). From a population-based perspective, New Zealand is multicultural with 67.6 percent of the population being European, 14.6 percent Māori (the indigenous people), 11.1 percent New Zealanders (previously this group was included under the European category), 9.2 percent Asian, 6.9 percent Pacific peoples and 0.9 percent as being Middle Eastern, Latin American or African (Statistics New Zealand, 2007: 4). Over the past 20 years, the Asian and Pacific peoples’ populations have had the greatest rates of increase (Maidment, 2009). The multicultural reality of New Zealand occurs within the context of a bicultural polity between Māori and non-Māori derived from the Treaty of Waitangi (1840; see Taylor, 1976). This in turn provides the background against which narratives of a New Zealand national identity and nationhood have emerged (Belich, 2001; Ruwhiu, 2001, 2009). This is evident in New Zealand’s two official languages, that is, English and Māori and the incorporation of Māori customs such as the haka (ceremonial dance) by national sporting teams and powhiri (a formal ceremonial welcome) to visiting dignitaries. In other words, present day New Zealand society is constituted by the historical relationships between Māori, the government and migrant settler groups.

Prior to European settlement in the 19th century, Māori had established systems of care within their tribal structures (whanau, hapu, and iwi; Ruwhiu, 2001). These systems included supervisory concepts and terms, for example, Bradley, Jacob and Bradley (1999: 4) refer to the following traditional roles as pertaining to supervision: kaiawhina (helper), kaitautoko (supporter), kaiwhakahaere (organizer), kaiarahi (guide), kaiwhakariterite (planner), mangai tautoko (advocate), takawaenga (liaison or mediator), kaiwhakatutuki or kaiwhakatinana (implementer), whakaruruhau (shelterer), kaitiaki (guardian), mana whakahaere or pou whakahaere (manager), and tautohito or matanga or pukenga (expert).

The importation of British social policies and welfare provisions followed the signing of the Treaty of Waitangi in 1840 and an influx of European settlers (Ruwhiu, 2001). According to the Treaty of Waitangi, Māori hapu (tribes) and the British crown were partners in a process of nation-building and settlement: the crown was permitted to establish a government, while the Māori tribes retained their rights of chieftainship, self-determination, and management of their resources and treasures, and also gained the rights and privileges of British subjects (Orange, 1987; Simmons et al., 2008). Between the 1850s and 1890s, however, there were numerous breaches of the treaty on the part of the crown and the settler governments and, by 1890, the settler governments had effectively colonized New Zealand through law, war, land confiscation and the suppression of Māori cultural practices (Belich, 2001; Ruwhiu, 2001; Simmons et al., 2008).

The charity-based welfare services that were established in the late 19th century were influenced by the British system, with voluntary charity services developing into public welfare agencies. While there is no evidence indicating whether or not the welfare workers were supervised, it is likely that they were overseen and received administrative supervision similar to that provided by the Charity Organizations Societies in the United States (US) (Burns, 1958; Kadushin and Harkness, 2002; Munson, 2002; Tsui, 1997, 2005). In the first half of the 20th century, as the New Zealand government developed the welfare state, the occupational categories of welfare officer and social worker were established and full-time workers were employed in the child welfare, probation, and medical social work fields (Nash, 2001; O’Donoghue, 2003; Schofield, 2001). The supervision of these workers was a mix of administrative and apprenticeship models and was focused on job performance and skills (Drew, 1987; Nash, 2001; O’Donoghue, 1999). At this time, the development of social work supervision in New Zealand lagged far behind that in North America, where both the field practicum and social casework supervision were well established (Burns, 1958; Rabinowitz, 1987; Robinson, 1936; Tsui, 1997).

Growth in the number of welfare officers, probation officers and medical social workers within New Zealand led to a demand for professional education and training. In 1950, Victoria University in Wellington offered a diploma in social sciences based on British and North American casework methods of social work, supervision and social administration (Nash, 2001). As it relied on fieldwork supervisors, the programme was motivated to improve the educative aspects of supervision and to increase the number of New Zealand social workers, who were formally educated and, in turn, took on supervisory roles (Austin, 1972). Over time, the increase in formally-trained social workers led to a demand for professional recognition and the establishment of the New Zealand Association of Social Workers (NZASW) in 1964 (Nash, 2001). The members of the association worked on establishing a social work profession and educating social workers through supervision; they did not debate the merits of autonomous practice versus interminable supervision because supervision was viewed as integral to the development of social work practice in New Zealand (Epstein, 1973; Munson, 2002; O’Donoghue, 2003; Rabinowitz, 1987; Tsui, 1997; 2005).

sec.title: The development of a social work supervision literature
sec.p: From 1965 to the mid-1980s there were various strategies adopted to develop social work supervision. NZASW initially led these efforts, establishing the first social work supervision course in 1965 and publishing Supervision in Social Work: A New Zealand Perspective (1972), a collection of papers, many of which were presented at a conference held in 1970 (NZASW, 1966; Robb, 1972). Despite these initiatives, few contributions were made to the literature on supervision, a fact that was decried by Bracey (1978), who noted that, in 38 issues of New Zealand Social Worker, only four articles dealt with supervision. Bracey (1978) compared the literature on supervision in New Zealand with the international supervision literature of the time, and particularly to Kadushin’s study (1974) and his classic book Supervision in Social Work (1976). Bracey (1978) was a passionate advocate for the development of research and writing on supervision practices in New Zealand. He noted that supervision training courses had continued without interruption at both of the Department of Social Welfare’s training centres since 1965, and drew attention to a pilot survey of 25 respondents on the practice of supervision conducted by the Manawatu Branch of NZASW. Generally, the developments in social work supervision in New Zealand in the 1970s were loosely aligned with those occurring in North America, indicating the growing influence of international literature, and particularly the work of Kadushin (1974, 1976), on the development of supervision practice and training in New Zealand. Bracey’s (1978) arguments and the pilot survey were indicators of the increasingly-international context of the attention devoted to social work supervision (Chernis and Egnatios, 1978; Kadushin, 1974; Munson, 1975, 1979).

In the 1980s, two academic research studies were conducted, namely Bowden (1980) and Bracey (1981). These studies contributed to the professional and educational aims of supervision in New Zealand. Bowden’s study (1980) was undertaken in the Department of Social Welfare and found that, while supervisors experienced satisfaction in the performance of their tasks, they also had difficulty balancing agencies’ administrative requirements with those expectations of their supervisees. One of the outcomes of this study was the establishment of the first New Zealand supervision qualification, the Certificate in Social Service Supervision from Massey University, which was offered from 1984 until 1992. Bracey’s study (1981) was conducted in the probation service and contributed to the development of supervision in that field during the 1980s and early 1990s. It portrayed supervision as the process by which practitioners are accountable for their practice and to their organization. Another development was the publication of the Supervision Resource Package (1985) by the New Zealand Social Work Training Council (NZSWTC). This national training package included a position paper, development plans, an extensive bibliography, and brief outlines of supervision models from a number of practice settings. Notable amongst the models were a bicultural model and a feminist model, which illustrated the growth of awareness during this period of the effects of colonization and patriarchy (Beddoe and Randal, 1994; Shannon, 1991). The bicultural model challenged non-Māori supervisors and practitioners to develop an understanding of Māori culture, by placing an emphasis on ‘the concepts of “whanaungatanga” (relationships), “mana” (respect) and “rangitiratanga” (leadership)’ in the supervision of Māori staff and social work practice with Māori clients (NZSWTC, 1985: 79). That said, despite the development of a wider bicultural awareness in both society and within the social work profession, Mataira (1985) noted that Māori social workers continued to suffer from a lack of culturally-responsive supervision.

The professional and educational focus of social work supervision in New Zealand in the 1980s, combined with the recognition of gender and cultural differences, mirrored international developments. For example, in the area of research, in the 1980s there were studies conducted on a range of supervisory issues (see Eisikovitz et al., 1985; Harkness, 1987; Harkness and Poertner, 1989; Melichercik, 1984; Poertner and Rapp, 1983; York and Hastings, 1985). In regard to practice models there were a number of supervision textbooks published (e.g. Austin, 1981; Bunker and Wijnberg, 1988; Holloway and Brager, 1989; Kadushin, 1985; Middleman and Rhodes, 1985; Munson, 1983). While in relation to the effects of gender and cultural differences, the feminist and cultural minorities critiques stressed that traditional supervision was aligned with a white, male, Western, hierarchical perspective, which did not address the power issues identified in the structural, political and socio-cultural discourses on supervision (Brown and Bourne, 1996; Chernesky, 1986; Hipp and Munson, 1995; Kaiser, 1997; Matheson, 1999; Morrison, 1993). The critiques suggested new approaches and contributed to the development of feminist models (Chernesky, 1986; Hipp and Munson, 1995; Matheson, 1999); approaches that were anti- discriminatory and free from oppression (Brown and Bourne, 1996; Morrison, 1993); and the questioning of assumptions regarding power, authority and culture in the supervisory relationship (Kaiser, 1997; Tsui and Ho, 1997).

sec.title: The ascent of managerialism
sec.p: Towards the end of the 1980s, attention was directed to the low level of professionalization among New Zealand’s social workers and its influence on supervision. The areas of particular concern were the tendency for social workers to identify with their agencies rather than with their profession, and the increasing emphasis on administrative supervision to the detriment of education and critical reflection (Blake-Palmer and Connolly, 1989; Taverner, 1989). The initial effects of managerialism were apparent in a marked shift in emphasis from educational and professional development to conformance with organizational performance management and accountability systems. In short, supervision’s aims in education, development and critical reflection were neglected and eroded (Beddoe and Davys, 1994; O’Donoghue, 1999). The general unhappiness with this situation is clearly captured in the social work literature of this period, a typical example of which is an editorial published in Social Work Review, volume 6, number 5/6, that stated: ‘a decision had been made to emphasize the crucial role that supervision plays in ensuring social workers maintain professional and ethical standards in their practice. Supervision can be a way of ensuring that social work is not undermined by the imperatives of organizational efficiency’ (Barrett and Munford, 1994: 1).

The issue contained articles on supervision from a training perspective (Beddoe and Davys, 1994), a qualitative study regarding the supervision of care and protection of workers in a statutory social work agency (Young, 1994) and a brief outline of the essential features of social work supervision, which emphasized the importance of supervision as a professional process (Cockburn, 1994). Other attempts to resist the dominance of managerialism are evident in the publication of an annotated bibliography of local and international supervision literature (Bennie, 1995), the introduction of the Aotearoa New Zealand Association of Social Workers (ANZASW) supervision policy statement (ANZASW, 1998) and the establishment of qualifications in supervision by the Auckland College of Education (now The University of Auckland) in 1997 and Massey University in 1998 (O’Donoghue, 1998).

Managerial, organizational and professional changes also had an impact on supervision internationally, particularly in North America and Great Britain. There was a growing perception that supervision was essentially an accountability process: its administrative and managerial functions were emphasized through the use of contracts and a focus on task completion and job performance (Bruce and Austin, 2000; Coulshed, 1990; Kadushin, 1992; Morrison, 1993; Munson, 1993; Tsui, 1997, 2005). The reaction to the ascendance of managerialism in the international supervision literature was twofold. First, arguments were made for the separation of the managerial aspects and the clinical or professional aspects of supervision (Erera and Lazar, 1994; Gibelman and Schervish, 1997; Payne, 1994). Second, the importance of clinical or professional social work supervision to direct practice was emphasized, and social work supervision was linked with other forms of clinical supervision in psychotherapy and mental health professions (Rich, 1993).

sec.title: Professionalizing social work supervision
sec.p: Since 1997, there has been a marked increase in the volume of research and publications on the topic of supervision in New Zealand, most of which were undertaken after 2000. The research studies have been mainly concerned with specific supervision areas or fields of practice (Cooper and Anglem, 2003; Davys, 2002; Ellis, 1998; Eruera, 2005; Gillanders, 2009; Hirst, 2001; O’Donoghue, 1999; Shepherd, 2003; Simmons, 2006; Thomas, 2005; Virtue, 2007). The following were among the findings of these studies:

list-item.p: The ability to choose one’s supervisor and a constructive relationship with one’s supervisor are important factors that contribute to the success of the supervisory experience for the supervisee.
Supervision in New Zealand tends to be mono-cultural, reflecting the majority New Zealand European/Pakeha culture. Bicultural and Māori supervision are not well understood by non-Polynesian people.
Individual supervisory sessions in which supervisees and supervisors discuss the supervisee’s work are the main method of supervision.
There has been a shift from the traditional line-management supervision model towards a more mixed delivery model, incorporating peer and external supervision.
Professionally-orientated supervision contributes to the learning, development and practice of practitioners and their social service organization.

sec.p: Other works on supervision published since 1997 are presented in Table 1 according to supervision topic, author and year, and type of publication.

sec.p: With the exception of the articles and papers directly concerned with Māori and Pasifika models and approaches (Autagavaia, 2001; Bradley et al., 1999; Eruera, 2007; Su’a-Hawkins and Mafile’o, 2004; Walsh-Tapiata and Webster, 2004; Webber-Dreadon, 1999), the studies showed the strong influence of American and British ideas and models,1which were adapted to the New Zealand supervision practice setting. In addition, a number of articles (e.g. Beddoe, 1997a, 1997b; Beddoe and Davys, 2008; Cooper, 2006; Davys, 2005; Garland and Ellis, 2006; Morrell, 2001, 2003, 2005, 2008; Rains, 2007) drew ideas, concepts and models from counselling and nursing supervision literature; the most commonly referenced were Bond and Holland (1998), Carroll (1996), Inskipp and Proctor (1988, 1995), and Hawkins and Shohet (1989, 2000).

In another category of Aotearoa New Zealand supervision literature are the reports of practitioners about their experiences of supervision in Truell and Nowland (2002). These reports provide brief descriptions of supervision and reveal a wide variety of supervision arrangements: traditional supervision (involving both line management and practice), peer supervision, clinical supervision, group supervision, and cultural supervision. They also demonstrate how supervision has helped practitioners reflect upon, conceptualize and address casework problems, and led them to examine the dynamics, values and assumptions in their work and within themselves.

Overall, the portrait this literature presents of social work supervision in New Zealand is a pluralistic one: supervision differs across fields of practice and across practitioner populations with regard to form, functions, models and approaches. O’Donoghue (2003, 2006) identified the following forms of supervision:

list-item.p: student or fieldwork supervision (i.e. supervision of students in training);
managerial supervision (i.e. supervision conducted by a line manager focused on the management of the work);
clinical/professional supervision (i.e. supervision that is focused on client outcomes, the process of practice and the development of the practitioner’s knowledge, skills and attributes);
cultural supervision (i.e. supervision that focuses on the cultural development and competence of the practitioner, provided by a supervisor who holds the appropriate cultural knowledge); and

cross-disciplinary supervision (i.e. supervision in which the supervisor and supervisee come from different disciplines such as social work and counselling or social work and nursing; O’Donoghue, 2006: 95).

sec.p: In addition to the different forms listed above are differences pertaining to the location of the supervision, particularly whether it is internal or external supervision2 (O’Donoghue, 1999, 2003). For example, Field (2008) notes that, in child welfare agencies, a traditional model is usually followed wherein a supervisor with line authority undertakes the administrative, educational and supportive duties in individual supervision sessions, though, in recent years, this model has been supplemented by the group consultation model in the context of casework practice. In the health and the community probation field, there is a dual model of supervision: peer internal supervision is used for professional practice, and administrative or management supervision is undertaken by a team leader or manager (Cooper, 2006; O’Donoghue, 1999). This dual model is also used in the not-for-profit field and for the supervision managers; however, in these fields, clinical or professional supervision may be provided by externally-contracted supervisors (Bell and Thorpe, 2004; Hirst, 2001).

Differences in the delivery of supervision have also developed in response to indigenous Māori developments (Māori services for Māori), biculturalism (Māori and non-Māori working in partnership pursuant to the Treaty of Waitangi) and multiculturalism (the population-based recognition of ethnic and cultural diversity) (O’Donoghue, 2010). Indigenous Māori developments are apparent in the development of iwi (tribal) social services, Māori-specific teams within mainstream social and health services, and by the establishment of the Māori caucus of the ANZASW (Beddoe and Randal, 1994; Bradley, 1996; Walsh-Tapiata, 2000; Walsh-Tapiata and Webster, 2004). Eruera (2007: 143) notes that changes within the social services context have influenced supervision, and states that ‘Māori are beginning to develop written resources, research and training’. The most noticeable among these within the field of social work supervision has been the claiming of an indigenous position in relation to supervision through kaupapa Māori supervision, which Eruera (2005: 64) defines as:

disp-quote.p: An agreed supervision relationship by Māori for Māori with the purpose of enabling the supervisee to achieve safe and accountable professional practice, cultural development and self-care according to the philosophy, principles and practices derived from a Māori worldview.

sec.p: Biculturalism, on the other hand pertains to supervision involving Māori either as staff and/or as clients. Here the emerging model involves the incorporation of a Māori worldview, knowledge and cultural practices (such as rituals of engagement, e.g. hongi, which is a traditional Māori form of greeting involving the pressing of noses; and/or the use of karakia [spiritual incantations] at the beginning and ending of sessions). In this model, when cultural issues are raised they are explored, and the need for cultural advice and support is considered by the supervisor and supervisee, with the advice and support, if needed, being provided by cultural experts either within or outside of the respective organization (Bradley et al., 1999; O’Donoghue, 2010; Walsh-Tapiata and Webster, 2004; Webber-Dreadon, 1999).

According to O’Donoghue (2010) multiculturalism is apparent in supervision through: (a) the changing demography of New Zealand and its presence in client, social worker and supervisory populations; (b) cultural supervision being constructed from a multicultural perspective; and (c) through multicultural differences being the subject of supervision. One example of this is the literature concerned with the supervision of practitioners and clients of Pacific Island origins (see Autagavaia, 2001; Su’a-Hawkins and Mafile’o, 2004). Su’a Hawkins and Mafile’o (2004: 11) describe Pasifika cultural supervision as a ‘multifaceted yet ethnic specific’ process which may involve interactions between supervisors, practitioners and clients from diverse backgrounds (e.g. Tongan supervisor, Cook Island practitioner and Samoan client), as well as interaction within the same cultural groups (e.g. Tongan supervisor, Tongan practitioner, Tongan client). For Su’a Hawkins and Mafile’o (2004: 12) the focus of Pasifika cultural supervision concerns the ‘cultural development and capacity of Pasifika practitioners through reflection, critique and action’ and by recognizing that, in New Zealand, they operate in primarily non-Pasifika contexts, in which support is often needed to maintain a critical awareness of the dominant New Zealand culture and to practice effectively from a Pasifika cultural base. Despite the aforementioned example, O’Donoghue (2010: 276) notes that the development of a consistent and coherent multicultural response to supervision, which recognizes the different positioning of members of majority and minority cultural groups and the dynamics of cross-cultural and same-cultural engagements within Aotearoa New Zealand, has yet to emerge and is an area for further research.

The final population-based difference is that which occurs interprofessionally and/or across disciplines, wherein social workers clinically supervise or are supervised by colleagues from other professions such as nursing, psychology and counselling (Cooper, 2006; O’Donoghue, 2004; Rains, 2007).

Clearly the pragmatic acceptance of a variety of supervision practices, together with the openness to various forms of cultural supervision such as the Māori and Pasifika models, demonstrate that New Zealand supervision is clearly different from the broader international literature. Overall, the proliferation of literature and research since 1997 indicates that there has been a renewed appreciation of the professional aspects of supervision and an effective professional response to the effects of managerialism (Beddoe, 1997b; O’Donoghue, 2001, 2003).

sec.title: Towards a professional social work supervision culture
sec.p: In addition to the development of a literature base on social work supervision, there has been a growing awareness of the importance of supervision in social service organizations, in education and training programmes, and in professional associations in New Zealand during the last decade. Within social service organizations, this has been characterized by the development and implementation of supervision policy statements and the separation of administrative and professional functions of supervision. There has been an increase in peer and external supervision and an emphasis on supervisors’ training by means of short courses or other forms of support for those pursuing qualification (Beddoe and Egan, 2009; Kane, 2001; O’Donoghue, 2003). For education and training providers, there has been more emphasis on interprofessional and interdisciplinary supervision qualifications and on the development of training to enable supervisees to gain the most benefits from supervision (Beddoe and Davys, 2008; Morrell, 2005). ANZASW3 and the Social Workers’ Registration Board (SWRB) have been highly influential in ensuring that supervision attains professional status. ANZASW formalized the assessment of social workers’ competency by introducing a policy statement on the expectations of supervision (ANZASW, 1998). It also established a supervisors’ interest group, which has established practice standards for supervisors and a registry of members offering external supervision. In addition, ANZASW has amended its code of ethics, adding a section entitled ‘Responsibility in Supervisory Relationships’ (ANZASW, 2004a: 14–15; ANZASW, 2004b). ANZASW’s combined efforts have improved the quality of supervision in the social work profession.

In 2003, the New Zealand government passed the Social Workers Registration Act, thereby establishing a system of voluntary state regulations for social workers. Although the act contains only two references to supervision (in section 29, as a possible prerequisite to the acquisition of annual practising certificates, and in section 83, as a penalty that may be imposed by the disciplinary tribunal), supervision plays a significant role in the attainment of registration and the maintenance of a registered social worker’s practising certificate and competency (Hutchings, 2008). The SWRB policy statement emphasizes the importance of supervision to the attainment of full registration by defining ‘enough experience’ as 2000 hours of supervised post-qualification practice (SWRB, 2007a). In order to maintain a registered social worker’s practising certificate, practitioners must supply SWRB with a statement from their supervisor or manager attesting that they have had regular supervision (SWRB, 2008). To maintain a certificate of competence, practitioners must receive at least monthly supervision according to the registered social workers policy statement (SWRB, 2007b). SWRB’s Code of Conduct (2005) and Code of Conduct Guidelines (2006) reinforce the importance of supervision and its contribution to competent practice. The latter states: ‘Supervision is so fundamental to providing competent professional social work services that all employers must provide supervision, even if it requires them to look outside of their own organization for supervisors’ (2006: 8).

SWRB’s position that interminable supervision is fundamental to competent professional practice clearly departs from the prevailing view expressed in the international literature which holds that, while supervision is necessary in order for a practitioner to attain a licence or registration, sessions decline in subsequent years or are replaced by consultation (Barretta-Herman, 1993, 2001; Gray, 1990).

Overall, the themes and issues addressed in the New Zealand social work supervision literature show the influence of international scholarship but also demonstrate clear departures that reflect the New Zealand context. Since 1997, the following differences have become more pronounced: the recognition and acceptance of plurality and diversity in the practice of supervision; the development and implementation of culturally-based approaches by Māori and Pasifika practitioners; the focus on the concept and practice of cultural supervision; and the position that supervision throughout a social worker’s career is necessary to ensure competent professional social work practice.

sec.title: Implications for international social work practice
sec.p: The areas of difference identified earlier have three implications for international social work practice. The first pertains to the delineation between managerial supervision and professional (clinical) supervision in the dual model of supervision. This model could easily be adapted by the international community as a professional supervision option for social workers whose direct line supervisors are non-social workers. That said, the model raises questions about three-way accountability arrangements (i.e. between the line management supervisor, the professional [clinical] supervisor and the supervisee) and the respective mandates of peers and external contractors. The degree to which these supervisors are sanctioned to supervise practitioners with regard to their well-being and development, and with regard to their practice, must also be clarified. Overall, the plurality and diversity of supervisory practice in New Zealand indicates an evolution in supervision and a change in the relationship between supervision and consultation.

The second implication arises from the response to the complex dynamics of cultural difference in supervision. The New Zealand supervision model addressed this issue by developing culturally-specific approaches to supervision. This development highlights the differences between supervision involving cultural insiders and supervision that is cross-cultural. The international social work community would be well advised to look at New Zealand’s example in order to determine the role of supervision in the cultural development and well-being of social workers from indigenous and minority groups, and in the development of the cultural competence of social workers from majority and dominant cultural groups.

The final implication relates to the professionalization of social work and the role of supervision in reinforcing the professional status of social work. The role of New Zealand’s professional body (ANZASW) and regulatory authority (SWRB) in maintaining the connection between supervision and competent social work practice has implications for other jurisdictions where the provision and position of supervision have been challenged.

In conclusion, the development of social work supervision in New Zealand demonstrates both continuities and differences with the developments charted in the international supervision literature. The main differences are the pluralism and diversity of supervision in New Zealand, the development of culturally-based approaches, the implementation of cultural supervision, and the endorsement that professional (clinical) supervision throughout a social worker’s career is necessary to ensure competent social work practice. The implications of these differences for supervision internationally pertain to the evolution and development of social work supervision itself, the role supervision plays in the cultural development and cultural competence of practitioners, and the upholding of professional standards when the profession’s status is challenged. That said, perhaps the most important international implication is the development of New Zealand’s supervisory culture, in which the praxis of supervision is fundamental to professional social work practice.

fn.p: The sources most frequently referenced were Brown and Bourne (1996), Hughes and Pengelly (1997), Kadushin (1976, 1992), Kadushin and Harkness (2002), Morrison (1993, 2001), Munson (1993, 2002) and Payne (1994).

Internal supervision is provided by a supervisor employed by and working within the organization, and may be provided by a colleague through peer supervision or by a line-manager or team leader. External supervision, on the other hand, is supervision provided by a supervisor who is not working within the organization but is contracted as a consultant to provide supervision.
NZASW changed its name to the Aotearoa New Zealand Association of Social Workers (ANZASW) in 1998.
